text: Speaker John Boehner and President Obama
met in the White House this weekend for
the latest round of talks over the
fiscal cliff and the long-term debt deal
right now it seems that there's growing
sentiment among Republicans that they
should just pass the tax cuts for 98
percent of households and then negotiate
everything else later on next year
senator bob Corker laid out that plan on
Fox News Sunday this weekend a lot of
people are putting forth of theory and I
actually think it has merit where you go
ahead and give the president the 2%
increase that he's talking about the
rate increase on the top 2% and all of a
sudden the shift goes back to
entitlements that means one part of the
next phase of negotiations will be
determining what entitlement cuts
Democrats and Republicans can agree on
one option for instance although a
controversial one would be raising the
Medicare eligibility age so you could
receive that benefit not at 65 but 66 or
even 67 this is something that the White
House has put on the table in the past
but it's something that's very
controversial Republicans like it
because it cuts costs from Medicare but
Democrats don't like it because it
doesn't cut the overall health spending
nationally here's representative Raul
Grijalva on ABC this weekend I think
that one of the issues that's being left
alone in this whole discussion is the
amnesia how we got into the situation
who's responsible for the situation and
to blame the three programs that we're
talking about Medicare Medicaid and
Social Security as the drivers of this
deficit is a mistake here's what we're
looking at for this week negotiations
are now primarily between the President
and John Boehner and they're trying to
hash out a deal in private that both of
their bases can accept so look for a lot
of leaks and a lot of senators and
Congress persons coming out to to argue
for certain provisions that they want or
don't want included in a deal but
anything from Obama and Boehner
themselves is going to be especially
important and is going to signal that
they might be getting closer to an
agreement before Christmas
